description: The best auto complete. The best features to help you be productive working with message queues, databases, etc.. Flawless integration with build tools like Maven. Awesome plugins by the community for lots of things.
summary: The best Java (and everything else, really) IDE

description: the best for java
I really love this IDE. It helps me a lot with the dev routine
Switching to IntelliJ has changed my whole development process for the better.

The people who rant about IDEA's resource consumption must be using bad hardware. I run it on a no-frills HP laptop 8 gigs of RAM, Intel core i5 8th gen, no ssd and I can run Chrome, and whatever other tools I need without any lags or crashes. The ONLY thing that's slow is the load time of the app. So relax, stretch out, and enjoy the best refactoring, best code completion, best code analysis and flexible IDE available. I run it on Arch Linux and Windows 10, same results.

I have been a Java developer for a few years, now. I used to work with Eclipse (and Eclipse-based IDEs) for the first 3 years. Then, I had an opportunity to try IntelliJ and the quickness, responsiveness and ease of use of this IDE was miles ahead of Eclipse. I know, Eclipse is just fine now (I still use it once in a while), but whenever I can, I use IntelliJ.

All (smart)autocompletion features, quick templates, great indexing, Docker and Spring integration plugins, pretty nice lambda debugger and multiple shortcuts makes my every day work way easier than it used to be.

I happened to work with one legacy multi-multi-multi-maven monorepo project where IntelliJ had to consume loads of resources and required some time at start up, but anyway, it was the only IDE (well, besides Vi /Vim :P) capable of running this project and not crashing after a few minutes.

I like intellij. I mostly use the pycharm plugin, but an intellij licence gives access to nearly all languages supported by JetBrains. The snap install is excellent too, it updates fast and has access to RC channels.
summary: A beast of an IDE, rules the jungle

description:
I tried both Eclipse and 'Intelli J'. I felt this one is way better than Eclipse. Intelligent code compilation, fast, stable. You will rarely see this IDE breaks, I had a very rough experience with Eclipse.
If you are learning Java then definitely go for this one. You will love it.
Very important feature for beginner is code quality (clean code and readibility: this IDE will suggest you with best practice). For me this one is go to IDE, love using this.
summary: the BEST I have tried for JAVA

description: the best java IDE ever :D
it is a good one

The fact that I can add it from Ubuntu's built in Software manager is even better. As an independent contractor for software development and devops, I find it indispensable. I now make all the junior developers I manage, install Ubuntu, partly because of this. Regarding some user's comments about power consumption on a laptop battery, my response is, if you want power, be prepared to provide power. It's only obvious. If you want to save power, then use a simple text editor - computing power does not come from magic you know.
summary: Best IDE I ever used on any platform

description: This app works fine for all kind of project.
love this ide, well done.
Is an excellent app for java Developers. The best!!
I use it for go/java development. There's really not a better option atm

I use intellij for web, nodejs, and python development. In each case, they do amazing things with their semantic understanding of the code. As a result, I'm convinced I write better code, faster than I would otherwise.

You can see this effect when you install anything from snap & apt. 
There is launch time difference, Execution delays, etc.
summary: snap is bad when you compare it with apt or JetBrains Toolbox

description: The price is extremely steep. If you were going to write anything other than Android, Java, or a Java language like Scala, or Kotlin, I might suggest another product, but for any of the languages listed above, InteliJ is a classic case of "Getting what you pay for". No one should write Java with a free editor like V.S. Code, or Sublime, however; that is not to say that those editors don't have their strong points, just Java Stuff is a bit complex for them. The reason for 4/5, and not 5/5 is due to the steep price.
Make developer life easy

Yes there is a fee, but they say you get what you pay for.

Its like tasting the forbidden fruit, once you have tasted it. You cannot untaste it -- you will be stuck for life.
